div3.head:
Wanted--
one hundred negro men.
div3.p: We wish to hire for the balance of the year , one hundred able-bodied negro men, to work at the Salt Works, in Smyths and Washington counties, Va. We want them chiefly for woodchoppers and teamsters, and we will pay twelve dollars per month, furnish board and clothing, and pay traveling expenses to and from this place; also, the expenses of any master or agent who will bring six or mere hands.
This section is perfectly quiet, but owners can remove their slaves from here whenever they deem them in danger from the enemy.
We refer to McDaniel & Irby, Lynchburg, and Spotis & Harvey, Richmond, who will pay our hires monthly or quarterly.
We hope hands will be sent us at once, without waiting for us to hunt them up. Boys and indifferent hands not wanted.
Saltville April 24, 1862. ap 29--2w*

div3.head: Maryland Partisan Corps.
div3.p: --It is proposed to organize a Partisan Corps of Maryland men, to act as nearly as possible on the frontier of our own State.
The corps to consist of Cavalry, Artillery and Infantry, and to be under command of Colonel Walter II, Jenifer, who has the same.
Horses will be furnished to the who desire to join the cavalry, if unable to provide their own.

The Secretary of War having decided that Marylanders are exempt from the previsions of the Conscription act, all twelve months men from that State can claim transfer to this corps at or after the expiration of their term of service.
Pay, rations and bounty same as in regular service.
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 10--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: Hdq'rs Second Military class, Richmond, May 10th, 1862.
div3.p: orders No. 5.--The several companies of this class will assemble on Monday, 12th inst., at their respective hours and places of drill, when and where all persons liable to duty therein are required to report themselves for muster and inspection.
Captains will keep their companies on the ground until the arrival of the inspecting officer.
Captains Allen and Hiltzhimer's companies will be divided and new ones organized.
div3.closer:

John B. Danforth,

div3.head: Scott's Partisan Rangers.
div3.p:
Having been authorized by Major Scott to raise a company, as part of his corps of Partisan Rangers, to be supplied with Williams's breach-loading mounted rifle.
I am prepared to receive any and all effective men not now in service; and I appeal especially to exiles from Kentucky, Maryland, and Northwestern Virginia.--Our commander was Captain of the celebrated Black Horse Cavalry, that proved so destructive to the invaders at Hull Run and Manassas.
He will lead us into the very heart of the enemy's country, and enable us to strike terror to the minions of the miserable tyrant who has dared to wage a merciless war upon the young Confederacy of the South.
Let there be no lack of heroic men to follow him.

The gun with which this company will be armed is the most wonderful and destructive weapon of the age. It can be loaded and fired from 20 to 30 times per minute, and will shoot with precision from three-fourths of a mile to a mile, when loaded with ball, and when loaded with buck-shot or musket balls, it will scatter death and destruction in the face of the foe at the distance of from three to five hundred yards. Indeed, it may be confidently affirmed that one company, armed with this weapon, will do more fearful execution than a whole regiment supplied with ordinary infantry arms.
Besides promising to be the most effective arm of the public service, the members of this corps will be entitled, in addition to the pay of regular soldiers, to compensation for all the arms and munitions of war captured from the enemy.
Persons desirous to engage in this most desirable and attractive branch of warfare, will please apply at once to the undersigned, Bank street, near 12th, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer: my 9--6t* E. E. Orvis.

div3.p:
One hundred Dollars reward!
Deserted from my company, at present stationed in the vicinity of Massaponax Church, near Fredericksburg, the following men, for the delivery of whom to me at the above post, or to Capt. Alexander at the Provost prison in Richmond, one hundred dollars reward for each will be paid, viz: Austin S. Dempsey, Samuel H. Mosier, and Eugene R. Grinnan.
A. N. Dempsey is 22 years of age, 5 feet 4 inches high, has dark hair, hazel eyes, fair, ruddy complexion, and was born in Baltimore.
Samuel H. Mosier is 23 years of age, 5 feet 3½ inches high, light, brown hair, light, blueish eyes, full face, sallow complexion, well built, and halls from Louisiana.
Eugene R. Grinnan is 21 years of age, about 5 feet 9 inches high, has dark, brown hair, gray eyes, and fair complexion — halls from Georgia.
And I hereby forward all persons from harboring, or in any manner aiding the above deserters, as the law will be rigidly enforced against all so offending.

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders!
div3.p: The following copy of a letter from Hon. Geo. W. Randolph, Secretary of War, sets at rest all doubts as to the position of Marylanders under the Conscription Act:

div4.head: [copy.]

dateline.name: Confederate States of America, War Department, Richmond,

opener.salute: Capt. R. C. Smith, Co. "C," 1st Maryland Reg't, Cars Major J. A. Weston, Richmond, Va.:

div4.p: In reply to your letter of the 22d ult., you are respectfully informed that the Maryland companies are not subject to conscription, and will go out of service when their term of enlistment expires.
This applies to all Marylanders, as shown by the following extract from another letter from the Secretary of War, dated April 26th.
"In reply to your letter of the 17th inst., you are respectfully informed that Marylanders are not subject to the Conscription Act.

By this decision all twelve months Marylanders who have been re- enlisted under compulsion, are entitled to their discharge or transfer, and all who have re-enlisted voluntarily have still the privilege of electing the company or regiment which they will join.
my 5--6t*

div3.head:
Second Company
Johnson's Light
Artillery.
div3.p:
More recruits are wanted for this company forthwith.
The conscription will soon be passed, mustering into the service every man in the Confederacy between the ages of 18 and 35, leaving no option with the conscript as to where he shall go, or to what arm of the service he shall belong.

All those who prefer to select the Light Artillery as their service should take at once the last opportunity they will probably have to volunteer.
We desire, at the earliest possible moment, to complete our organization and take the field, where all who are fit for service should be, and where they must be soon, either voluntarily or by compulsion.

Those who have been in service know that the Light Artillery is the most agreeable as well as the most effective arm of the service.
Come at once, then, while the chance is given you to enlist where you please, and relieve yourselves from the opprobrium of compulsory service.
Recruiting Office, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
James H. Hackett,
ap 15--ts John H. Leftwich.

div3.head: Headquarters ordnance Departm't, Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
mh 29--tf Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.
div3.p: --I have received the requisite authority to enlist a corps of Partisan Rangers to serve during the war.

The corps is designed to consist of Mounted Riflemen, Cavalry, and Infantry, and have attached to it a company armed with the light howitzer.
I propose to operate within the enemy's lines and will be enabled to hold out the prospect of a more active life than that which falls to the lot of the regular soldier; at all events, the members of the corps will not be subjected to the tedium of camp life.

I cordially and most earnestly invite all who desire to enter the Partisan branch of the service to unite with me, and all companies and battalions not mustered into the Confederate service.
I desire gentlemen who propose to unite with me to bring with them such private arms as they may be able to command — shot-guns, rifles, pistols. &c.

The wolf is hunted for his scalp, and our Government has determined to pay for all arms and munitions of war which we may capture from the enemy; thus placing the invaders of our country and the oppressors of our liberty upon the footing of the savage beasts of the forest, to be captured or slain at all times and by any means not prohibited by legal warfare.

I invoke all enterprising men to join me, who are not engaged in the military service, and especially those whose homes are in the possession of the enemy.--I invoke them to join me whether animated by a simple love of country, or a hatred of the public enemy; whether they have a wrong to redress, a vengeance to slake, or a home to protect.
Gentlemen wishing to raise companies for the corps, will address me at Richmond city, Va., or apply in person at my recruiting rendezvous, in this city, at the Palmetto House, corner 2th and Main st,
div3.closer:
John Scott,
my 7--ts Of Fauquier, Capt. C. . A.

div3.head:
War Department, Adj't and Insp. Gen.'s office, Richmond, May 3d, 1862.
General orders--no. 84.
div3.p: I. The following proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:

div4.head: Proclamation.
div4.p: By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:

q.p: I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the counties of Lee, Wise, Buchanan, McDowell, and Wyoming, under the command of Brigadier-General Humphrey Marshall; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception, of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name, and set my seal this the 3d day of May, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.

div4.p:
II. Brigadier-General Humphrey Marshall is charged with the due execution of the foregoing proclamation.
He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:

q.p:
All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the safe thereof will be closed.

div4.p:
III.
All persons infringing the above prohibitions will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial; provided, that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th article of war.
div4.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
(Signed) S. Cooper.
my 5--6t Adj't and Insp. Gen'l.

div3.p:

Prepayment of $30 per month will be required Children under ten years and servants half price.
[ap 9--4w] Henry Easley.

div3.head: Soldiers from Yorktown, attention!.
div3.p: --The notes of the Peninsula Bank, issued at Yorktown by C. H. Wynne, will be redeemed at his Printing House, corner of Main and Fourteenth streets, Richmond.

Soldiers are cautioned against disposing of them at a discount, as they will be redeemed at par value.
my 9--1w*

div3.head: Office Va. Savings Bank, Richmond, May 7th, 1862.
div3.p:
the Legislature of Virginia having required, at its last session, the Savings Banks to redeem their issues, the note holders of this institution are requested to present them at once for redemption.
Office at the store of E. R. Spence, corner of Main and 18th streets. Office hours from 9 A. M. to 3 P. M.
my 7--2w* T. B. Starke, Tress'r.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: The Notes issued by the Corporation of Fredericksburg will be redeemed by us at a discount of ten per cent.
R. H. Maury & Co.,
Office south corner Main and 11th sts.
my 1--ts

div3.head: Office of the old Dominion Insurance Company, 140 Main st., Richmond, April 15, 1862.
div3.p: Removal.--The office of this Company has been removed to No. 140 northwest Corner of Main and 12th streets, where they will be pleased to see their customers.
Charles E. Wortham,
ap 15--ts Secretary.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Many Shinplasters, signed by "Wm. A. J. Smith, " having been presented at my counter for redemption, I would state that I am not the author of them, nor have never issued a shinplaster of any kind.
My name is
Wm. Ira Smith, and not
ap 21--ts Wm. A. J. Smith.

Cotton

Cotton Cards,
No. 8 and 10, which are now offered for sale.
Graveley & Pringle,
ap 15--1m* 52 East Bay. Charleston, S. C.

div3.p: A good
Cook,

without encumbrance.

Cox's Line.
freight boats
div3.p:
From Richmond to Lynchburg are now running regularly.
For freight apply to Wm. P. Cox, Agent,
At the Shed, Dock street,
ap 18--1m* in rear of old Gas Works.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Our senior partner Mr. Moore, being in the army, we have for the present closed our store.
Our books will be found at the store of Mr. Jno. Dooley, who is authorized to receipt in settlement of all accounts.
Those indebted to as will greatly oblige us by calling and settling the amount of their accounts as early as possible.
mh 14--3m C. T. Moore & Co.

div3.head:
Crockery Ware.
Crockery Ware.
div3.p:
In addition to my usual well-assorted stock of China and Glassware, House-furnishing and Fancy Goods.
I have replenished my stock of Crockery Ware, so that I am enabled to offer my customers and the public a splendid assortment of Plates, Cups and Saucers, Ewers and Basins Water Pitchers, &c., &c.
Julius Meyer,
Late Partner of Schasp & Co.,
my 6--1m* Corner Broad and 3d sts.

div3.head: Notices.
div3.p:
--Having disposed at the balance of our stock of Goods on hand, we have concluded to discontinue business for a season from 1st of May. Those indebted to us, on account or by notes, would oblige us to call at our old stand and settle the same.
Those having bills against us will present them and get their pay.
J. Millhiser & Bro.
my 2--2w* 193 Broad street.

div3.head: City Scavenger--
div3.p: To Citizens of the City of Richmond.--Please to leave your orders with Mr. Duval, corner of 10th and Main streets, and at Millspaugh & Johnston's, corner of Main and 18th streets. [my 1--1m] R. H. Allen.

div3.head:
For rent--
two Parlors,
div3.p: with folding doors, and small side room.--The rooms will be rented with or without furniture.

Also, for sale, privately, some good and useful articles of Furniture.
Apply at first brick house above 3d street, on Main street, north side.
my 1 --2t*

div3.head:
For rent — a
House and Furniture,
div3.p:
on Cary, between 3d and 4th streets, (third door from 4th street.) The House has six rooms and several closets.
To a good tenant, the rent will be moderate.
Apply at the House, of at No. 12 Pearl or 14th street. my 10--ts

div3.head:
For rent — a
furnished House.
div3.p:
A large three-story House, in one of the best location in the city, with most of the standing Furniture, for rent or lease, to a permanent tenant.
Apply on Main street, between 2d, and 3d, right hand side, first three-story house.

Also two Servants to hire.
my 9--8t*

div3.head:
For rent--
a brick House
div3.p:
on Franklin street, between 18th and 19th streets.
Possession can be had on the 12th inst. E. D. Eacho,
my 9--8t 14th street.

div3.head:
Very desirable residence
for sale.
div3.p:
My residence at the corner of Marshall and 12th streets, is still in market for sale.
If desired, the Furniture will be sold with the house.
Persons desirous of buying, will be shown through the building.
Wm. F. Butler,
my 6--5t No. 19 Pearl street.

div3.head:
For rent — a
House and Lot,
div3.p:
On, 7th street between Marshall and Clay streets, formerly occupied as a School- house.
It will suit a small family, or for any mechanical or other business.
Inquire at No. 89 Main street, or at No. 235 Broad street. my 3--6t*

div3.head: For rent.
div3.p:
--For rent, and possession given immediately, the very desirable Store occupied by the subscribers.
It is one of the best stands for a Clothing House in the city, having been occupied as such for the last 18 or 20 years.
Darracott, Harris & Co.,
112 Main street.
P. S.--We would also dispose of the entire Fixtures at low prices. D., H. & Co.
my 3--ts

div3.head: Pottsville for rent.
div3.p:
--The undersigned will rent for the balance of the year the place in Louisa county, Va., known as Pottsville, containing sixty-one acres, well in proved, on which is a dwelling-house with some six or seven rooms in good repair, all the out buildings necessary for the comfort are convenience of a family.
This place is within 1½ miles of the Virginia Central Railroad, in a pleasant and healthy neighborhood.
Any person wishing further information, will address the undersigned at Levits store, Spotsylvania county, Va.
ap 18--4w E. McCLOUD.

div3.head: For rent.
div3.p:
--The office now occupied by us, under St. Charles Hotel.
Possession given about 1st April.
mh --ts R. H. Maury & Co.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, near Dayton, Marengo county, Ala., my dining-room servant, James, sometimes calling himself James Clarke, a bright mulatto, about twenty-five years of age, slightly bowlegged; was raised in Richmond, Va., by a Mr. Totty.
His parents still live there.--James was in the army last summer at Winchester.
A reasonable reward will be paid for his apprehension and confinement in jail so that I get him again.
my 10--1m* Edward Baptist.

div3.head: Runaway--$10 reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the above reward for the apprehension and delivery to me of a mulatto boy named William, sometimes called Ben. He is about 16 years old; full head of hair; about 5 feet high; stout and well build.
He has been raised to waiting in the house, and was hired to Mrs. Joses, on Broad st. when he left.
He belongs to Mr. Jas. C. Ray, of Henrico [my 10--3t*] Jas. Moore Main st.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, from John Quarles's brickyard, in the city of Richmond, where he was hired for the present year, on or about the 15th of April, a negro boy named Humphrey.
He is about 20 years old, well built, quite dark and full featured, with a small scar on one of his cheeks; no other scar or mark recollected.
He generally looks down when spoken to. The last time he was seen he was on the York River cars, supposed to be on his way to Yorktown or some other place on the peninsula.
He may have passed himself off as a free negro and hired himself to some company, as a good many soldiers were on the cars the day he was seen on them.
The above reward will be paid if delivered to Miles C. Eggleston, in the city of Richmond, or to me, in the county of Hanover, near Old Church Post-Office.
my 9--5t* Wm. Parsley.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my saw mill, in Buckingham county, on Monday, May 5th, 1862, my negro man, named John.
Said negro is about 22 years old, ginger-bread color, quite stout, and wide across the shoulders, and about 5 feet 4 or 5 inches high, and usually wears a cap. I bought John in March last, at the auction room of Dickinson & Hill, in Richmond, of Mr. George Turner, of Prince William county, Va., where he has a wife, and may endeavor to get back.
The above reward will be paid upon his delivery to my overseer, Mr. Payne, or to myself, in Richmond.
my 9--6t* Truman A. Parker.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Wednesday last, a negro boy named William, lately purchased of Mr. David Lyon, of Petersburg.
William is about 21 years of age, 5 feet 8½ inches high, black complexion, two false teeth set on gold plate, wore when he left a soldier's shirt, and is a bricklayer by trade.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me in Richmond, Va., or for his confinement in jail so that I get him again.
my 9--6t* David McDANIEL.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the residence of Dr. F. W. Hancock, a , young, and likely mulatto woman, named Rose, about 22 years old. She was hired a part of last year to Col. Weston.
I will give the above reward for her apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond, or put in some jail so I can get her.
my 9--6t Wm. S. Phillips.

div3.head: Ranaway--$10 reward.
div3.p:
--On Friday, 28th of March, my girl Jane.
She is 14 years of age, dark, well grown, tall and stout, flat nose and forehead the forefinger of the right hand is off up to the first joint, occasioned by a whitlow.
I think she is in Richmond with her mother.
The above reward will be paid if secured in jail so that I can get her, or to E. D. Eacho.
my 9--3t Oliver Garthright.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my house, on the 5th inst., my negro boy, Joe. He is 5 feet 4 inches high, ginger-bread color, and a butcher by trade.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me, at my house, or my stall at the Old Market.
my 7--6t* Joseph Kirsh.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--A reward of $20 will be paid for the recovery of my servant boy, Taylor, who left my house about the 19th of April. He was seen to get on board of the York River Railroad cars, in company with some soldiers, on their way to Yorktown, who were supposed to belong to Gen. Longstreet's division.
Taylor is about 14 years old, rather small for his age, of dark ginger-break color, ready and smart in his address, and very rightly in manner.
Address. Francis W. Hancock,
Chief Surgeon 3d Division, or
Dr. Jas. E. Williams,
my 7--ecd5t Richmond, Va.

div3.head: $5 reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the undersigned a ale red Buffalo Cow, with a heavy crop in one of her ears, thought to be the right.
to have a calf just about this time.
Any information thankfully received and the above reward paid for her delivered to me on 17th street, near the old Distillery.
my 5--eod3t* John L. Eubank.

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--The subscriber will pay the above reward for the apprehension and delivery at the 16th Alabama regiment, or the jail in Richmond, of two negro Boys, who made their escape from the above-named regiment, in the neighborhood of Rappahannock, about the 13th March, ult., and who are described as follows, viz: Jim, of light complexion, about 5 feet 10 inches high, stammers, when spoken to, weighs about 160 pounds, and has a large near on his forehead.
Charles, of dark complexion, about 6 feet high, slender of measure, and of about 165 pounds weight.
Captain P. V. Gusery,
Lieut. . P. Head.
Rappahannock, Va., April 8, 1862.

div3.head: $25 reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick act, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
S. S. Cottrell,
ap 2--ts No. 129 Main street.

div3.head: Administrator's Notice.
div3.p: --All persons indebted to the estate of Alex. B. Hutcheson, dec'd, will please make payment to the undersigned without delay; and all those who have claims against and estate will please present them, with the evidence on which they rest, to the undersigned as soon as possible.
John A. Hutcheson,
Adm'r of Alex. B. Hutcheson, dec'd.
fe 24--ts

div3.head: For sale — a valuable Tract of Land.
div3.p:
--I have for sale a tract of Land lying in the county of Lunenburg, five miles of the Court-House, adjoining the land --also, Messrs. Joel Parish, John Orgain, Jr. and others — lying on Flat Rock Creek, 608 acres, a large portion in original growth.
improvements consist of a dwelling house, two rooms above and two below; out-house burns.
The land is well watered and is a neighborhood.
I deem further description necessary.
Any person willing to buy will and examine for himself, and I will tell him bargain.
Robert Bolling
New Plymouth P. O., Lunenburg co.,

div3.head: Neat framed Tenement on North side of Main between 30th streets, together with Household ture, for sale.
div3.p: --At the request of Mr. S. Hartman, we offer for sale the framed dwelling located as above, now in his occup It has 5 rooms, besides kitchen, &c. Also, household furniture, &c.

Terms reasonable.
Apply to
Goddin & Apperson, .

div3.head: 263 acres of excellent Land
div3.p: adjoining Manchester, and on the Manchester Turnpike, for sale are authorized to sell at private sale 263 acres of excellent land located as above, a portion of which is in a high state of tion, and admirably adapted to farming purpose.

The improvements are a comfortable dwelling, in a grove of beautiful trees, the usual out-buildings.
A plat of the can be seen at our office.
Apply to
J. M. Taylor & Son,
my 9--4t Auctioneer

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p: I offer for sale five hundred acres of Land in the county of Prince Edward, waters of Bush river, six miles from rin Depot, on the Richmond and Railroad, and six miles from Prince C. H. The land is of excellent quality than one-third of the tract is in timber original growth and pines; and eighty hundred acres of rich low grounds, The pavements are ordinary, consisting of sser's House, four Negro Quarters, and sufficient to house twenty hog she tobacco, Corn Crib, &c. For terms, &c., to P. B. Sublett,
Commission Merchant,
Shockoe Slip, Richmond
my 8--eod6t*

div3.p:

It is nearly and has every modern improvement usual first-class dwelling, and ample accommodate for a large family.
Apply to

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p:
--My Farm, in the county Goochland, lying on James river, 2 miles from Richmond.
This Farm 730 acres, with fine residence, good houses, &c. A portion of the land is James river and creek low grounds.
Terms liber Apply to me, on the farm, or to R. G. Mo Esq., Richmond.
my 7--6t* W. N. Barest

div3.head: Sussex Land for sale.
div3.p:
The subscriber offers for sale a tract of in two miles from the Petersburg and Richmond Railroad, at a point 24 miles from Petersburg containing 460 acres, with large and convenient dwelling-house, &c. The corn and der will be sold with the place.
Possess gives immediately, if desired; if not, 1st of January next.
Address
J. B. Freeman,

my 8--1m* Coman's Well, Sussex.
Jr.

div3.head: For sale--
div3.p: A large and convenient
dwelling-House, with extensive out houses and grounds, interior town of Virginia, not very from Richmond.
For particulars, inquire at this office.
my 8--1m

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p: --I will sale at the late residence of Mrs. Hobson, one mile from Amelia Court-House on Thursday, the 15th of May, 1862, Tract of Land of which she died possessed, containing about 60 acres, with comfortable buildings; also, a choice selections fruit trees.
Terms on day of sale.
S. S. Weisiger,
my 1--12t* Executer.

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p:
--I offer for sale Farm, on the Appomattox river, in the county of Prince Edward, six miles Farmville, and within one and a half miles of the South-Side Railroad.
It contains acres; but it can be made smaller to accommodate purchasers.
The improvements consist of a two-story dwelling, recently built an office, and every necessary out-building, in good repair.
It has between 80 and 100 acres of creek and river flat land; a sufficiency of wood and timber, and a good portion of the open land is finely set in clover.
For further information in regard to it, I refer to my friends John A. Dalby and A. Morton, Farmville.
My address is Yorktown, care of Capt. Jas L. Thornton.
ap 24--1m John H. Knight.

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p: --I will sell privately acres of Land, in the county of Goochland within two miles of the James River , is two miles from the county seat.
Also, if desired, 100 acres of Wood Lan adjoining, making a tract of 400 acres.

There is on the first-named tract a good dwelling-house, barn, tobacco, and other out-house.
Possession given immediately, if desired, I the subscriber, at Goochland C. H. din & Apperson, Richmond, Va.
ap 23--1m* Thos. R. A Gy

div3.p:
A large furnished Room, suitable for persons, can be obtained in a pleasant neighborhood in Albemarle county, Virginia Central Railroad.
Also, two nished Rooms.
Terms, $30 per month, able monthly.
No children can be Address "C. E.," Keswick, Albemarle, Va.
my 8--eod4t*

div3.p: Two Rooms can be obtained, with or without Board, and the use of the Bath, in a private family, in one of the most desirable portions of the city, and near the Capitol.
Address "Box 451" my 5--eodt*

div3.p: A few gentlemen can obtain
Board, or Rooms without board, by applying.
my 9--3t* On 4th st., beyond Jackson

Dividend.--The Directors of this Company have this day declared a dividend of Twenty per cent., payable to the stockholders and the 15th instant, until which date the Transfer Book will be closed.
J. H. Montague.
my 8--td Secretary.

dateline.name: Office Va. F. Marine Co., Richmond,

div3.p: Dividend Notice.--The Directors of this company have declared a semi annual dividend of ten per cent., payable in the stockholders on the 15th inst., until which date the transfer book will be closed.
my 5--t15 Secretary.

dateline.name: Office Richm'd A Petersburg R. E. Co., Richmond, Va.,

div3.p: Notice.--The Board of Directors have declared a dividend of four per cent. on the capital stock of this company, payable on and after the 5th inst., to all who were Stockholders on the 1st inst., said dividend to be in of that usually declared on the 1st of July. The transfer books will be closed from the 3d to the 5th inst., inclusive.

my 2--3w M. W. Warrington.
Tress't

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --A dividend of 2½ per cent. on the capital stock of the Richmond, Fredericksburg, and Potomac Railroad Company was declared on the 23d inst., payable stockholders or their legal representative the office of the company on the first day of May next, (1862.)
ap --12t C. W. Macmurdo, Tress't

div3.head: Spring Millinery.
div3.p: Mrs. Demelman, on south Main street, between 17th and 18th, has on hand a superior stock of
Millinery

and other goods, and invites her old friends, and the Ladies generally, to call and supply themselves.
She is prepared to make beautiful spring style Bonnets with expedition, and solicits orders.
Her store is closed every Saturday.
Mrs. D. is prepared to Bleach Bonnets and hats in the best manner.
Three or four Young Lady Milliners will find
